facts.text: Petitioner held contracts for supply of milk to Government Hospital at Cannanore, Kerala State, ever since 1946, and his brother held similar contracts from 1936.
In 1957, uniform procedure for fixing contracts adopted, conditions for acceptance of tenders laid down by notification.
Petitioner and third respondent (Co-operative Milk Supplies Society, Cannanore) submitted tenders for 1958-1959 supply of milk and other articles.
Tenders to be opened by Superintendent of Hospital in presence of interested parties.

Tender conditions: no tender marked at current market rates accepted; preference to approved Co-operative Milk Supply Unions/Societies if tender within 5% over market rate or lowest tendered rate; all tenderers to produce solvency certificate, tax clearance, deposit.
On January 20, 1958, petitioner's tender for milk supply accepted, third respondent's rejected.
Superintendent (respondent No. 2) communicated reasons for acceptance/rejection to Director of Public Health.

Correspondence between Director of Health Services and second respondent resulted in petitioner informed that contract cancelled due to Government policy to give contracts to Co-operative Milk Supplies Union on prices fixed by Revenue Department.
Further correspondence: second respondent instructed to act under Cl. 20 of tender conditions, give one month's notice before cancellation.
Second respondent issued notice under Cl. 20 and cancelled contract after notice period.
Petitioner filed O.P. No. 201 of 1958 under Art. 226 in Kerala High Court, rejected by Raman Nayar, J. on June 6, 1958.
Letters Patent Appeal (A.S. No. 354 of 1958) dismissed by Koshi, C.J. and Vaidialingam, J. on July 7, 1958; High Court held it was contract breach, remedy by civil suit, not Art. 226.
No special leave to appeal sought from Supreme Court against High Court orders.

legal_issues.text: Whether cancellation of petitioner's contract for supply of milk infringes fundamental rights under Articles 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g) and 31 of the Constitution, amounting to discrimination vis-a-vis third respondent.
Whether a contract for supply of goods constitutes 'employment' under Article 16(1).

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled to equal treatment in the eye of law; discrimination against petitioner vis-a-vis third respondent.
Cancellation of contract infringes fundamental right to practise profession, occupation, trade or business.
Denied equal opportunity of employment under the State.

respondent_arguments.text: It was Government policy to give contracts for supply to medical institutions in Cannanore District to Co-operative Milk Supplies Union on prices fixed by Revenue Department.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioner did not acquire absolute right to continue in contract; power reserved under Cl. 20 to terminate after one month's notice. Whether exercise regular/legal to be decided by Civil Courts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adjudication of contract dispute not under Art. 32; remedy in ordinary Civil Courts.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination under Art. 14; Government, like private party, can choose contractor to their liking.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Choice of person to fulfil contract left to Government.

court_reasoning.text: Breach of contract, if any, entitles to sue for damages or specific performance, but not deprivation under Art. 19(1)(g).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contract from Government not different footing invoking Art. 19(1)(g).

court_reasoning.text: Art. 16(1) confined to employment in service, not contractors supplying goods; petitioner selling milk, not servant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contract for supply not 'employment' under Art. 16(1).

court_reasoning.text: None of Articles 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g), 31 applicable; no fundamental right involved.

holdings.text: Cancellation of supply contract does not infringe Arts. 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g), 31; no fundamental right involved; dispute is contract breach for Civil Court.
Art. 16(1) applies to employment in service, not to contracts for supply of goods.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art. 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g), 31; previous proceedings under Art. 226 dismissed.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art. 32 dismissed as wholly misconceived; no fundamental right involved; matter is at best breach of contract to be pursued in Civil Court for damages if advised.

key_quotes.text: No doubt, the petitioner claims to have succeeded in obtaining the contract from the Government, and the third respondent failed to do so. But even if he held the contract, the petitioner did not acquire an absolute right to be continued in that contract...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains no vested right in contract due to termination clause.

key_quotes.text: When one person is chosen rather than another, the aggrieved party cannot claim the protection of Art. 14, because the choice of the person to fulfill a particular contract must be left to the Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Article 16(1) of the Constitution, both in its terms and in the collocation of the words, indicates that it is confined to employment by the State, and has reference to employment in service rather than as contractors.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of Art. 16(1) excludes supply contracts.

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved.
key_quotes.speaker: court
